anatomical location body part affected: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) impacts the entire individual
description: ASD is a newly defined disorder in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM -5) published in 2013 that encompasses 4 diagnoses that in the DSM-IV  and ICD-10  were included under the term pervasive developmental disorder (PDD)(51) –This reflects scientific consensus that the 4 previously separate diagnoses are a single condition with different levels of symptom severity

ASD encompasses the following previously separate diagnoses: –Autism(51) –Asperger’s disorder(51) –Childhood disintegrative disorder(51) –Pervasive developmental disorder–not  otherwise specified (PDD-NOS)(51)
Individuals with a well-established  DSM-IV  diagnosis of autism/autistic disorder, Asperger’s disorder, PDD-NOS,  or childhood disintegrative disorder should now be given the diagnosis of ASD(1)
ASD is characterized by(1) –deficits in social communication and social interaction –restricted repetitive behaviors, interests, and activities (RRBs)
Both components are required for a diagnosis of ASD(51)

Severity of ASD is defined based on amount of support required as follows:(51) –Level 1: Requires support -Social communication -Without supports in place, the deficits in social communication cause noticeable impairments -Difficulty initiating social interactions and precise examples of atypical or unsuccessful responses to social overtures of others -Might appear to have decreased interest in social interactions -RRBs -Inflexible behavior causes significant interference with functioning in one or more contexts  -Difficulty switching between activities -Organizational and planning difficulties impair age-appropriate  independence –Level 2: Requires substantial support -Social communication -Marked deficits in verbal and nonverbal social communication skills -Social impairments apparent even with supports in place -Limited initiation of social interactions -Reduced or abnormal responses to social cues from others -RRBs -Inflexible behavior, difficulty coping with change, or other RRBs that appear frequently enough to be obvious to the casual observer and interfere with functioning in a variety of contexts -Distress and/or difficulty changing focus or action –Level 3: Requires very substantial support -Social communication -Severe deficits in verbal and nonverbal social communication skills causing severe impairments in functioning -Very limited initiation of social interactions -Minimal response to social cues from others -RRBs -Inflexible behavior, extreme difficulty coping with change, or other RRBs markedly interfering with functioning in all realms -Great distress/difficulty changing focus or activity

Rationale for the new diagnostic definitions and criteria: –A perceived lack of precision with the former diagnostic categories; different clinicians would diagnose different disorders in the same person(52) –A belief that there is a common set of behaviors that can be characterized according to severity(52) –There is a spectrum of manifestations that vary greatly depending on the severity level, developmental level, and chronological age(51)

Assistive technology and communication supports for persons with ASD can be used to enhance, expand, and develop communication skills(53) –Children with ASD often have difficulty with spoken and written language expression, understanding spoken language, and understanding gestures, body language, and tone of voice used to convey differences in meaning. Motor planning problems can interfere with ability to coordinate the muscles needed for speaking, writing, or using sign language(53) –Augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) approaches include unaided approaches (signs, gestures), “low-tech” picture-based  systems (e.g., Picture Exchange Communication System [PECS]), communication books and boards, speech-generating  devices (SGDs), and portable word processors (e.g., iPads)(53) –Specialized communication-related  applications for devices such as tablets and smartphones are becoming more widely available(58)

This Clinical Review focuses on assistive technology and communication supports for persons with ASD. For detailed information about assessment and treatment of persons with ASD, see Clinical Review…Autism Spectrum Disorder ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708583

reimbursement: There are several issues pertaining to reimbursement for therapy and assistive technology for persons with ASD

The U.S. Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) of 2004 states that each public agency (school) must ensure that assistive technology devices and/or assistive technology services are made available to a child with a disability if the child’s Individualized Education Program (IEP) team determines that the child needs access to those devices in order to receive free appropriate public education (FAPE)  –This law requires schools to use assistive technology devices and services to maximize accessibility for children with disabilities –If the IEP team determines that a child needs assistive technology devices and services, the school district is responsible for providing these and cannot use lack of availability or cost as an excuse for not doing so –IDEA 2004 also requires schools to provide assistive technology training for the teachers, child, and family

Before obtaining any assistive technology for a child with ASD, it is necessary to have the child evaluated by an expert who can assess the child’s specific needs and guide the use of the technology. This typically involves conducting a feature-matching  analysis that matches technology features to the needs of the child –An assistive technology evaluation may be obtained through a child’s school, or privately through specialized centers. Schools often contract out the evaluations to assistive technology experts or independent evaluators

Many organizations offer grants and other assistance for children with ASD. Examples include Easter Seals, the National Autism Association (United States), the Adam Scott Foundation Autism Grants Program (Australia), Apps for Children With Special Needs (A4cwsn), iHelp for Special Needs, and the iTaalk Autism Foundation. State-run assistive technology programs may also provide funding. The Autism Society maintains a resource database at http://www.autismsource.org/

Laws in many states in the United States now require insurance companies to pay for some ASD evaluation and treatment, while other states have legislation pending. There has been significant resistance to these policy changes from some healthcare companies and advocate groups, citing a lack of high-quality  studies addressing behavioral treatments
presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation –In the United States, current estimates are that ASD has been diagnosed in 1 in 68 children(2) –The prevalence of ASD has increased dramatically over the past 30–40  years. The reasons appear to be multifactorial and include the following: heightened public awareness; improved screening and evaluative tools; the change in diagnostic criteria and categories in the DSM  since autism was first included in the DSM-III  in 1980; passage of the IDEA in 1990, which provided services in the school system to children in whom ASD was newly diagnosed as well as children in whom the condition was diagnosed under a different educational label such as “mental retardation,” speech impairment, or learning disabilities.(57) ASD is commonly diagnosed around age 4 years; however, parental concerns about their child’s behavior generally begin around 12–18  months of age(3)

Early signs/symptoms(3) –Impaired social communication (e.g., does not respond to name being called) –Impaired play skills (e.g., does not imitate others’ actions) –Impaired language and cognition (e.g., little to no babbling) –Regression (e.g., loss of language skills) –Impaired visual skills (e.g., impaired tracking) –Impaired motor skills (e.g., delayed acquisition of walking) –Impaired sensory integration (e.g., cries when donning clothing) –Altered eating and sleep habits

General signs/symptoms –The extent of symptoms can vary tremendously from person to person. There is generally some level of impact on an individual’s communication, social abilities, and response to his or her environment(51) –Delay in acquisition of developmental motor milestones(54) –Perseverating behaviors and inflexible routines are characteristics of ASD(4)

Specific signs/symptoms –Social manifestations -Little to no eye contact(5) -Persons are regarded in the same manner as objects(5) -Lack of sharing(5) -Lack of peer interaction(5) -Out-of-place  laughter(5) -Appear as if they are “in their own world”(5) -Inability to read the expressions/faces of others or pick up on social cues(5)  -Some children may hug, make eye contact, or even smile, but this interaction is only periodically observed(6) -Inability to empathize(7) -Lack of “joint attention,” which is the ability of a child to engage the attention of another person to share enjoyment of objects or events(6) -The child may point to ask for something (e.g., a card depicting lunch selections) rather than verbally explain something(5) -Does not respond to verbal commands or respond to name(5) -Echolalia (i.e., repetition of a word or phrase spoken by another person)(5) -Limitations or delays in expressive and receptive language(5) -Inability to participate in pretend play(5) -Hyperlexia or premature decoding ability with little understanding of text(5) -Refers to self in the third person(5) -Impaired comprehension of irony or sarcasm(4) –Behavior/sensory manifestations -Sensory processing impairments; individual might have a decreased perception of pain and an increased sensitivity to light touch, for example(4) -Perseverating(5) -Lining up of objects without purpose for play(7) -Walking on toes(5) -Preoccupation with components of items(6) -Enjoyment in watching objects spin(5) -Intense reactions to change(59) -Flapping of hands(8) -Biting(7) -Head-banging(7) -Insomnia(9) -Tantrums(59) -Decreased coordination(8) -Gait deviations(8) -Atypical posturing(8) -Mild hypotonia(4) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Generally accepted that there is an atypical pattern of brain maturation in children with ASD(8)

Possible genetic link–In the case of identical twins, if one twin has ASD the risk of the second twin being affected by ASD is 36–95%(2)–In fraternal twins, the risk is up to 31% for the unaffected twin to later develop ASD(2)–If one child in a family has ASD, the risk in subsequent children is 2–18%(2)–Genetic irregularities have been found in all chromosomes except 14 and 20 and in mitochondrial genes in individualswith ASD(6)
pathogenesis: Physiological findings–Studies have found that the head circumference of children with ASD generally has an atypically increased growth ratebetween 6 and 14 months of age(6)–Toddlers with ASD appear to have a larger brain volume with noted enlargement of the cerebellum, amygdala, andcerebrum compared to typically developing peers(6)
risk factors: Males have been reported to be 3–4 times more likely than females to have ASD. Male-to-female  ratios of up to 9.5:1are reported when higher functioning individuals (e.g., in whom Asperger’s syndrome previously was diagnosed) areincluded(54)
Prenatal complications, including maternal rubella and phenylketonuria (PKU)(6)
factors not associated with an increased: No correlation between increased prevalence of ASD and use of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine–No association between ASD and MMR vaccine based on systematic review of 12 articles(11)–No association between ASD and MMR vaccination in retrospective study conducted in Denmark involving 537,303children(12)–No association between MMR vaccine and PDDs in case-control study conducted in the United Kingdom involving 1,294cases and 4,469 controls; 78% vs. 82% had MMR vaccination before diagnosis (or matched age)(13)–No association between MMR vaccine and ASD in community-based case-control  study conducted in the UnitedKingdom with 98 cases and 142 controls(14)

No association between vaccines that contain thimerosal (a preservative that contains mercury) and ASD–No association between ASD and thimerosal-containing  vaccines in systematic review of 10 epidemiological studies;studies suggesting association were poor quality, and results could not be interpreted; 2 pharmacokinetic studies foundthat ethyl mercury has a short half-life,  making association improbable(15)–No association between ASD and thimerosal-containing  vaccines in cohort of 467,450 children from a study conducted inDenmark(16)–No consistent association between thimerosal-containing vaccines and any adverse neurodevelopmental outcome inretrospective study conducted in the United States involving 140,887 children in 3 HMOs(17)–No association between thimerosal-containing  vaccines in infants and developmental disorders in prospective UnitedKingdom cohort of > 14,000 children(18)–No association between thimerosal-containing  vaccines in infants and developmental disorders in retrospective UnitedStates cohort of 109,863 children(19)–Early thimerosal exposure not associated with neuropsychological deficits at ages 7–10  years(20)
Infection in the first 2 years of life is not associated with ASD(21)

No association between ASD and defined gastrointestinal disorders (celiac disease, necrotizing enterocolitis, chronicdiarrhea, malabsorption, food intolerance, recurrent gastrointestinal symptoms)(22)
No association between ASD and neonatal hyperbilirubinemia(23)

overall contraindications precautions: Training Clinicians would benefit from required training/instruction on the emotional needs of the parents Clinicians should include the family/caregivers in the treatment sessions, explain and demonstrate therapeutic strategies, and provide oral and written instruction as indicated
No contraindications specific to ASD are listed in the literature reviewed

Precautions should be taken when treating patients with ASD due to potential for: wandering behavior/elopement  self-injurious  behavior poor safety awareness impaired balance poor impulse control rigid adherence to routines communication deficits

If child has a coexisting seizure disorder, seizure precautions apply(24) Eliminate dangerous objects from area Stay with the patient Do not hold down extremities Release restrictive clothing Follow aspiration precautions (e.g., rotate head to side, assess airway, wait for tonic-clonic  activity to pass before administering artificial respiration, if indicated)

course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Do they appear to be effective for the intended purpose?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed

Per the practice parameter developed by the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (AACAP) Committee on Quality Issues (CQI) (available on the National Guideline Clearinghouse website), the diagnosticians should use the following steps for diagnosing ASD:
Screen all children for symptoms of ASD during routine developmental assessments(81)
For those children in whom screening indicates increased risk of ASD, review all medical history and conduct a
thorough examination using the criteria from the DSM5  to determine the presence of ASD(81)

A multidisciplinary assessment (including genetic testing, hearing assessment, psychological testing, communication assessment, and physical and occupational therapy assessments) should take place for all children in whom ASD is diagnosed(81)

Following completion of multidisciplinary assessments, diagnostic clinician should ensure that the child with ASD and family members have access to therapeutic interventions for all identified needs(81)
According to the DSM-5, criteria for diagnosis of ASD indicate that the patient must have:(51)
persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts as manifested by the following:
Deficits in social-emotional  reciprocity
Deficits in communicative behaviors used for social interaction
Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships
restricted repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities as manifested by at least two of the following, currently or historically:
Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech
Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns
Highly restricted fixated interests
Hyper-  or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of environment
symptoms originating in early childhood, but that may not be fully manifest until social demands exceed capacity
(e.g., during middleschool  years, later adolescence, or young adulthood). This is a change to the DSM-IV  criteria for autism that symptoms must be present by the age of 3 years
A diagnosis of ASD can be made by a pediatrician (generally a developmental pediatrician), pediatric psychiatrist/ psychologist/neuropsychologist, or neurologist(25)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document use of any home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., diet modification) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy, speech language therapy, or applied behavior analysis (ABA) for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Document what education the caregiver/family has received pertaining to ASD

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document strategies that are calming to the child and situations that typically induce maladaptive behaviors
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, and any difficulty falling asleep; how many hours of sleep does the child get (total and naps)? Sleep disturbances are common in children with ASD(26) -Children who lack adequate, consecutive sleep for their age have difficulty with the ability to concentrate and focus, attend to a task, have less patience, are more irritable, and are fatigued compared to those with adequate number of hours of sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Gastrointestinal problems are common in children with ASD. If a child shows new signs of developmental regression he or she should be referred to physician for investigation of possible medical causes Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________  See Assessment below

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask parent/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, epilepsy, psychiatric disorders (e.g., anxiety, depression), attention deficit disorder, attentiondeficit/hyperactivity disorder, and orthopedic disorders. Intellectual disability is common in children with ASD(59)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs or herbal supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask parents about other symptoms the child is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the child attend school in a traditional setting, or is the child home-schooled? Does the child receive any therapy services through the school district? Is the child involved in extracurricular activities or sports? Does the child have regular play dates? What are the child’s hobbies or favorite things to do?  -If school-aged,  obtain information from child’s teacher or other school staff where indicated and available
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What ADLs can the child perform independently? -Any adaptive or assistive devices currently used -What training in assistive technology and communication supports has the child and/or family received?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., siblings/caregivers/ group home). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? How is the child able to negotiate the school environment?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Evaluation of the child with ASD will vary depending on the age of the child, the severity of symptoms, and the setting in which the child is being evaluated. Standardized assessments paired with clinical observations tend to be the most common methods of evaluation. The clinician should modify the examination as indicated and appropriate depending on the child’s needs and current functional status; the information presented below is meant to serve only as a guide
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate balance reactions in sitting and standing as indicated and appropriate. The Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) can be used(63)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Monitor respiration rate and heart rate at rest and during activity to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels. Does the child need frequent rest breaks? •Functional mobility (including transfers)

Screen child forage-appropriate  bilateral coordination tasks such as jumping, jumping jacks, cross marching, skipping, galloping, standing/hopping on one foot, ability to participate in catching/throwing/kicking a ball. Note any abnormality, asymmetry, or difficulty completing these tasks

Document child’s motor planning ability for novel tasks and whether visual and/or verbal demonstrations were required for participation in tasks. Did the extra cues increase success with task completion?
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess the child’s gait as indicated; note any gait deviations or asymmetryAssess bilateral upper and lower extremity joint mobility, noting the presence of hyper-  or hypomobility. Clinicians can use the Beighton Hypermobility Score to aide in assessment of joint laxity(64) Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess child’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremity muscle tone. Can use Modified Ashworth Scale to indicate present of hypertonicity and/or spasticity –Observe whether the child can cross midline with his or her UE/LE during age-appropriate  gross and fine motor skills (bilateral coordination/motor planning/sequencing task)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) would be appropriate to test upper and lower extremity strength and trunk strength if the child is able to follow the directions and does not have abnormal muscle tone or coordination deficits. Can use hand-held dynamometry to measure strength instead of MMT –Can use functional-based  tasks to assess strength such as the ability to wheelbarrow walk, hang from a trapeze bar, complete knee push-ups/full  push-ups,  maintain a plank, maintain a wall slide, or propel a scooter board in prone if manual muscle testing cannot be completed effectively -Use strength category of the Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)(59) -Ask child to get into positions such as prone and supine; note trunk extensor/flexor strength  Neuromotor development –Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development-Third Edition(59)motor, cognitive, and behavioral -Can be used up to 42 months of age –Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)(59) -Can be used from birth to age 5 years –BOT-2(59) -Can be used from ages 4 to 21 years -Standardized test evaluating gross and fine motor skills –Early Intervention Developmental Profile (EIDP) -Can be used from birth to age 3 years -Evaluates development and identifies areas of delay –Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI)(59) -Can be used from ages 6 months to 7.5 years -Standardized test assessing functional skills, mobility, and social function –Sensory Integration and Praxis Test(59) -Can be used from ages 4 to ~9 years -Evaluates motor skills, sensory integration, and postural control Perception (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) –Ocular motor screening for tracking, convergence, saccades, binocularity, eye preference, disassociation of head/eye movements, eye contact –Document whether the child complains of ocular motor fatigue and observe for signs of fatigue, such as rubbing eyes, covering eyes, or turning body to compensate for reduced ocular motor skills –If standardized testing cannot be completed, document the child’s ability to complete puzzles appropriate to his or her age –Developmental Test of Visual-Motor  Integration (VMI) identifies problems in integrating or coordinating visual perceptual and motor abilities (finger and hand movement)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document posture in a variety of positions such as sitting, standing –Document presence of scapular winging, sacral sitting, rounded shoulders –Document posture during use of assistive technologies and communication supports
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess AROM and PROM for UE and LE as indicated. Often appropriate to assess during functional tasks Self-care/activities  of daily living (objective testing) –For children with ASD, the WeeFIM is appropriate for assessment of ADLs(27) -The WeeFIM assesses basic daily living and functional skills in children from birth to 7 years of age(27) -The WeeFIM is based on the functional assessment for adults known as the FIM and includes 18 items in the followingself-care,  sphincter control, transfers, locomotion, communication, and social cognition(27) -The PEDI is an appropriate test for ADL assessment when the WeeFIM is not sensitive enough to detect change –The Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) can also be used to assess ADLs. The COPM is a standardized test that detects change in a child’s self-perception  of occupational performance over time(62) –Child interview as able given age and cognitive status –Family/caregiver interview to identify level of performance with tasks that cannot always be observed during an outpatient/school evaluation (e.g., bathing, dressing) –Document if the child participates in household chores such as cleaning up toys, setting the table, emptying the dishwasher, laundry, or yard work
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Evaluate for the presence of a sensory processing disorder (SPD) and indicate if there are any hypo-  or hypersensitivities with relation to the tactile system, auditory system, vestibular system, visual system, or oral sensory system that impact the child’s daily functioning. This should be done through clinical observation and primary caregiver and child interviews –The Sensory Profile, Sensory Profile School Companion, Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile, or Infant/Toddler Sensory Profile (all created by Winnie Dunn) are commercially available tools that may assist with determining whether impaired  sensory processing is impacting the patient’s daily life and the need for assessment with an occupational therapist (OT) or physical therapist (PT) skilled in evaluating and treating SPD
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Prior to determining what assistive technology and communication supports are needed for an individual with ASD, a speech-language pathologist (SLP) will conduct a thorough speech and language examinationIf the child uses some speech for communication, use a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis to determine errors that have a high frequency of occurrence and are early developing and those that are functionally important for that child and child’s family. A sound inventory can be completed for children who have severely limited speech. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be calculated. In addition to errors at the segment level, the SLP should note other aspects that affect speech intelligibility, such as low volume, rapid delivery, or repetition of words.(65) For detailed information on assessment of speech sound disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicChildren with severe to profound ASD and ID may be in the early stages of communication. The impact of any motor difficulties should be considered when evaluating the child’s ability to respond to and initiate communication. Early communication can be assessed informally by means of a language sample and observation that document forms (i.e., gesture, vocalizations) and functions of communication (i.e., requests, comments)The CSBS-DP  can be used to assess expressive language, social communication abilities, and symbolic abilities by means of a parent report and directthe Infant-Toddler Checklist, the Caregiver Questionnaire, and a 30-minute behavior sample of the child. It can be used with all children aged 6 to 24 months and with children up to age 6 years who have a developmental age lower than 24 months(66)Used to assess prelinguistic communication behaviors in individuals with severe developmental and/or physical disabilities. Administered as a questionnaire to be completed by parents, teachers, and therapists. Pragmatic functions that are assessed include social convention, attention to self, rejection/protestation, request for an object, request for action, request for information, comment, choice making, answer, and imitation(67)Designed to identify how the child currently communicates and assist the assessment team on selecting appropriate communication goals. The assessment covers communication skills that would typically occur from birth to 24 months of age. It can be used for individuals of all ages who are at the earliest stages of communication(68)Assessment of receptive and expressive language should include a combination of formal and informal measures (language samples). Assessment of language comprehension (i.e., receptive language) is necessary to 1) determine how well the child understands spoken language input, 2) determine if augmentation of spoken language is beneficial to the child (i.e., visuals), 3) identify if there are discrepancies between the child’s comprehension and expression, and 4) determine the optimal way to teach AAC symbols.(65) Assessment of expressive language should provide information on the child’s functional communication skills, including the frequency of communicative functions,Informal language measures are useful to examine the child’s comprehension of language in different situations, the child’s responsiveness to communication, mean utterance length (MLU), word use/ vocabulary, echolalia, pronoun use, and pragmatics.(65) Informal measures can include observations of the child during home and school instructional and play situations as well as observation during specific elicitation activities. Elicitation measures can be used to encourage the child to communicate. The following are some techniques to elicit specific -Keep toys away from the child but within sight so that the child is required to request them(69) -Eat a snack in front of the child without offering the food to the child (to elicit requests)(69) -Provide a mystery box or opaque container with objects. When the child withdraws an object, he or she may comment on the object(69) -Engage in social routines (i.e., blowing bubbles) and provide an interruption so that the child may request continuation(69) -Elicit requests of parts of toys or puzzles by offering some but not all of the parts(69) -Pretend to misunderstand or not hear when the child speaks to elicit a conversational repair(69)  -Provoke a comment by doing something silly (e.g., wear funny hat) or by pointing to a noteworthy object (e.g., bandage on a finger)(69)Comprehensive test batteries for language can be used with children who are able to respond to test questions. Most formal evaluations of language have not been normed with children with ASD or other developmental disabilities, and this should be taken into consideration when reviewing test scores. The following areAges 1 year to 6 years, 11 months(70)Ages 5 years to 16 years, 11 months (has a pragmatic language component)(71)Ages  4 years to 8 years, 11 months (has a pragmatic language component)(72)Children with ASD have difficulty with pragmatic language, including narrative discourse. It is recommended that SLPs use informal language samples or published assessment tools to evaluateA caregiver-report rating scale for social and communicative behaviors such as social awareness, social information processing, ability to produce reciprocal social responses, and social use of language. It can be used with children and adolescents (4 years to 18 years)(29)A screening checklist of pragmatic language skills that can be completed by parents and teachers for children and adolescents. The child’s skills can be compared to a norm-referenced  sample(73)A checklist of pragmatic skills based on observation that can be used with both children and adults(74)A  measure that provides an inventory of a child’s communication abilities(75)A standardized measure that examines narrative comprehension and production in children aged 5 to 11 years(76)Provide a reading evaluation as necessary or refer to a reading specialist/special education teacher. Assessment includes letter identification, letter-sound  identification, phonological awareness skills, sight word reading, fluency, and reading comprehension. There are no reading assessments that have been standardized for children with ASD; adaptations might be necessary for administration and results should be interpreted with caution(77) Special tests specific to diagnosis  (used in research and/or clinical practice for clinicians who assist in diagnosing ASD) –Autism Observational Scale for Infants (AOSI)(28) -Measures multiple areas (e.g., visual attention, early play behaviors, behavioral reactivity, and sensory-motor development) pertinent to ASD and detects atypical findings in the young child -The evaluated behaviors are scaled from 0 to 3; 0 indicates typical functioning -Test-retest  reliability at 1 year of age is good –Childhood Autism Rating Scale–Second  Edition (CARS 2)(29) -Assists in quantifying severity of autistic symptoms in conjunction with screening for ASD itself -For children over age 2 years -~ 5 to 10 minutes to administer -Fifteen items on each form to evaluate by clinician -Includes standard and high-functioning  forms -Standard form – used with children < 6 years of age and children with communication impairments or below-average estimated IQs -High-functioning  form – used with verbally fluent persons ≥ 6 years of age with IQ scores > 80 –Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS)(29) -Created as a tool to screen for ASD -Can be used from toddler years into adulthood -Includes 4 modules -Takes ~ 30–45  minutes to administer each module -Standardized assessment  –Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT)(30) -Designed for use at 18-month  checkup -Screening tool used to detect signs of ASD -Completed by caregiver/parent and primary healthcare provider –Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT)(28) -Encompasses wider scope of developmental domains than the CHAT -Caregiver fills out questionnaire; no observational portion -Administered at 24 months -Includes 23 items –Screening Tool for Autism in Toddlers and Young Children (STAT)(31) -Designed to detect indicators of ASD -Administered at 2–3 years of age -12 items; takes ~ 20 minutes -Used to evaluate social and communicative behaviors –Gilliam Autism Rating Scale 2nd Edition (GARS-2)(29) -Assists in the diagnosis of ASD and labeling severity -Ages 3–22  years~ 5 to 10 minutes -Three subscales (stereotyped behaviors, communication, social interaction); 42 items -Norm-referenced  tool
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess child’s ability to communicate and level of arousal –Document length of time child is able to attend to activities, and what strategies may work to assist with redirection to task as appropriate –Did strategies such as concise, clear directions, visual schedules, or movement breaks allow for an increase in attention or participation? –Document frustration tolerance and presence of impulsivity –Is the child able to follow single-step  and multistep directions? –Document presence and level of eye contact –Document if the child becomes overstimulated with any specific tasks –Please see Special tests specific to diagnosis , below

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Expert consensus supports that early intervention (birth to age 3 years) can make a dramatic impact on outcomes in children with ASD.(2) Assistive technology and communication supports typically are beneficial for all individuals with ASD in some form, but must be individually tailored to match patient needs treatment _ During music therapy, communication is promoted (e.g., eye contact while singing) _ _ Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS)   (38) _ Designed to promote spontaneous communication in a social setting via pictures/symbols _ _ Joint attention training   (34)Centered around key communicative behaviors, including pointing/showing and eye contact (e.g., the clinician pointing to a toy and the child then looking at the toy) _ _ SGDs _ Please see Treatment summary , aboveProgress each unique child as indicated and appropriate _ _ When using PECS, the goal is for the child to progress through six levels of communication. This communication ladder ranges from the child making a request via a picture to answering a question(38)Implement a home program based on specific needs of child  Behavioral concerns/ impaired social skillsLimit behavioral outbursts/coping strategies when they do occur _ _ Improve social skillsVisual supports   (36) _ Might have a positive impact on behavior _ _ Includes pictures, signs/ symbols, or objects _ _ Example: a toy car to represent an actual car _ _ Video modeling   (35) _ Might facilitate the acquisition of target behaviors _ _ Generally the methodology consists of: Carefully selected recordings (of the child or others) are obtained of the desired behavior/skill The child views the recordings multiple times The child and therapist then reenact what was just observed on video Generalization is then monitored and practice continued as indicatedProgress each child as indicated and appropriateImplement a home program based on specific needs of child  Reduced comprehensionImprove comprehensionVirtual reality   (45) _ Can be used for visual stimulation, fostering imagination, abstract concept comprehension, and the promotion of perceptual learning _ _ Virtual reality can be tailored to each child’s needs (e.g., setting the program to best match the child’s learning style)Progress each child as indicated and appropriateImplement a home program based on specific needs of child Sensory integration issuesImprove coping abilities through a “sensory diet” or other sensory strategiesAuditory Integration Training (AIT)   (42) _ In theory AIT focuses on atypical sound sensitivity and attempts to “reeducate” the practice of hearing. AIT intervention normally includes 10 hours of auditory input via headphones (two 30- minute sessions a day for 10 days) _ _ Sensory stories _ Existing stories can be adjusted to fit the child’s program and goals _ _ Should be read multiple times per dayProgress each child as indicated and appropriate _ _ Sensory stories _ Eventually recitation of the sensory story is tapered once it becomes clear that the child is utilizing the techniques described in the storyImplement a home program based on specific needs of child .
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Schizophrenia Psychosocial deprivation Fragile X syndrome Tuberous sclerosis Rett syndrome Developmental coordination disorder
prognosis: ASD is a chronic, lifelong disorder(2)
Approximately 10% of individuals affected will later develop Parkinson disease or catatonic traits(8)
Functional use of language skills leads to better behavioral and medical outcomes(54)

Mortality risk in persons with ASD is 2.8 times higher than in persons without ASD of the same age and sex(60) –Based on a 2012 meta-analysis –The difference is related to co-occurring  medical conditions
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines IDEA mandates that public agencies in the United States must ensure that the IEP team for each child with a disability includes: –the parents of the child –no fewer than one regular education teacher –no fewer than one special education teacher of the child, or, where appropriate, no fewer than one special education provider of the child –a representative of the public agency (who has certain specific knowledge and qualifications) –an individual who can interpret the instructional implications of evaluation results and who may also be one of the other listed members –at the discretion of the parent or the agency, other individuals who have knowledge or special expertise regarding the child, including related services personnel as appropriate  –whenever appropriate, the child with a disability –assistive technology specialist –developmental pediatrician –SLP –OT –PT –neuropsychologist –applied behavioral therapist –audiologist(3) –ophthalmologist/neuro-ophthalmologist(4) –social worker/psychological support -In a study in the United States involving 5 families of children with ASD, researchers assessed how family members orchestrated their day-to-day  lives and the emotional impact of raising a child with a severe disability. The authors reported family members may rely on inflexible routines to manage their days and have trouble coming across daily activities that are upbeat and joyful(32) -An association between parental emotional stress and unfulfilled social and psychological needs was reported in a study conducted in the United Kingdom in which investigators interviewed 26 families of adults with ASD(33) –vocational therapy for adults with ASD
other considerations: Joint attention training –Improvements in imitation, play, spontaneous speech, affect, and social initiations were reported in a small study conducted in the United States involving 10 children (4 with ASD) that investigated the effects of joint attention training (joint attention was defined as the ability to coordinate attention between an object and a person in a social context(34) [e.g., child points out a toy to another child using gestures and eye contact])
treatment summary: Assistive technology and communication supports serve the child/caregivers in bolstering communication and facilitating emotional/behavioral growth
Incorporating multiple therapeutic strategies during the course of treatment of individuals with ASD typically is the most effective method(35)

There is a significant need for more randomized controlled studies that evaluate the efficacy of various treatment interventions for individuals with ASD. The studies described below primarily are nonrandomized or noncomparative (without a control group)

Visual supports and the Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS) –In a meta-analysis  of single case research studies on aided AAC systems for individuals with ASD, researchers found that AAC had strong effects on targeted behavioral outcomes -Most of the participants had a diagnosis of “autism” -Positive behavioral outcomes included communication, social skills, and spelling; additionally, there were reduced instances of challenging behaviors -The most effective forms of AAC were PECS and SGDs –Visual supports might improve communication skills in children with ASD(36) -Based on a randomized trial conducted in India -Thirty children were included in the study and were randomly assigned to the treatment group or the control group -Treatment strategies included objects, pictures, signing, and symbols -The Scale for Communication Skills was used for assessing communication abilities -Compared to baseline, a statistically significant improvement in communication skills was found in the treatment group post 14 individual instruction sessions that lasted ~30 minutes each –The use of PECS might offer individuals with ASD who have significant limitations in expressive language a successful means of communication(37)  -Based on a systematic review performed by researchers in Australia -Review included 27 studies (of varying methodology) with a total of 456 participants –In a pilot study conducted in the United Kingdom investigating the efficacy of PECS in children with autism, researchers reported significant (p < 0.01 for this study) improvements in the children’s use of the PECS, PECS vocabulary, and overall level of communication, as well as a reduction in negative behaviors(38) -Thirty-four  children were included in this noncomparative study -The stated goal of PECS in this study was to foster spontaneous communication abilities from the use of pictures or symbols in a social setting –In a case series investigating the benefits of various visual supports for children with ASD, researchers reported multiple accounts of success with the various supports implemented. Examples in which the goal of the visual support was met include the following:(39) -A visual schedule was created with pictures of exercises to facilitate a child’s participation in gym class -Photographs were placed on toy bins to assist the child in cleaning up his or her toys and reduce anxiety over the clutter in his or her room -Pictures were taken from old therapy catalogs and copied; the child would then circle the various activities he or she participated in that day as a strategy to communicate experiences to his or her family –Mother-implemented  PECS training was reported to be effective in teaching children with ASD to communicate with PECS and maintain this skill for ≥ 1 month; based on a case series comprising 3 mothers and 3 children (mean age 2.5 years) with ASD(40) –In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found that two 3-year-old  participants with ASD had a faster rate of learning with the PECS when video modeling (a video clip that depicts a representational model performing the desired behavior) procedures were used versus when the PECS only were used(41) –In a study in New Zealand comparing use of PECS, manual signing, and SGDs for acquisition of multistep requesting and social communication in 2 children with ASD, researchers found that both children acquired proficiency with all 3 options, but that 1 child demonstrated preference for using SGDs and the other preferred PECS(55) -The authors concluded that consideration of personal preferences is important when selecting AAC options(55) –In a study conducted in the United States comparing effectiveness of using PECS and an SGD to improve social communicative behaviors in 3 children with severe ASD, researchers found relatively little difference between the 2 options(56)

Universal design is a relatively new concept with respect to assistive technology, including AAC; the idea of universal design is to create devices that serve needs of a wide range of individuals—those with and without disabilities.(78) For example, there are many apps available for download on the iPad that allow it to become a high-tech  AAC device for a child with ASD, but the iPad can also be used by the patient’s parents, whose language abilities are intact.(79) For devices with universal design, no adaptations are necessary.(78) The iPad or other commercially available computer tablets also have the advantage of being highly socially acceptable, which is appealing to many parents who do not want their child’s AAC device to appear awkward or stand out –In a study conducted in the United States with 5 boys with ASD (mean age of 4.5 years), researchers compared PECS with an iPad-based  SGD to help the children acquire a mand repertoire.(80) Researchers used an alternating treatment design: after the initial baselines, subjects were randomly assigned to begin either PECS or iPad training and were trained in the second form of AAC after the first intervention was complete. The frequency of independent and prompted mands was used as a dependent variable for this study. The interventional mand training was performed in sessions with 15 trials each. In the mand training sessions, a researcher would present the participant with three preferred items and ask the participant to select one. When the participant reached for an item it was then placed out of the child’s reach, but within view, and the PECS or iPad with the picture of the item was placed in front of the child. If the child did not use the AAC to request the item within 5 seconds, the researcher modeled how to do so. Once the child had the preferred item, he was allowed to play with it for 30 seconds and then it was taken back for the next trial. At the conclusion of the study, researchers found that the overall rate of independent manding across training and maintenance intervals was higher for 4 of the 5 participants using the iPad-based  SGD. Individual results varied with respect to obtaining a level of mastery with the device: 2 participants more readily achieved mastery criteria with PECS and 3 more readily achieved mastery criteria with the SGD(80)

SGDs –Peer-mediated  instruction was reported to be effective in teaching 2 children with ASD to use SGDs during game activities and increase the children’s total appropriate communicative acts; based on a case series from Canada comprising 6 typically developing peers and 2 children with ASD(46) –In a case series from the United States, researchers evaluated the effects of enhanced milieu teaching and a voice output communication aid in children with autism. Investigators reported that the 3 children studied learned to use the communication device and that requests during play (overall) were increased(47) -Enhanced milieu teaching was described as a strategy to promote communication in a natural manner –In a case series from South Korea, researchers evaluated the impact of a voice-output  communication aid in comparison with a picture-exchange  system in children with autism. Investigators reported parallel acquisition rates for these interventions(48) -After the intervention, 2 of the 3 subjects favored the picture exchange system -One child preferred the voice output communication aid post intervention –In a case series from Sweden of 4 children with autism, researchers evaluated the efficacy of SGDs, with investigators reporting an increase in communicative effectiveness during specific daily tasks(49)

Auditory Integration Training (AIT) – in theory, AIT focuses on atypical sound sensitivity and attempts to “reeducate” the practice of hearing with the goal of improving behavior and/or facilitating learning(42) –Authors of a systematic review found insufficient evidence regarding AIT or other sound therapies for ASD(42) -Existing evidence is limited by very small studies -Poor methodology and inconsistent outcomes were found -Three of the studies included did not reveal significant gains as a result of AIT over control intervention -Three of the studies did report improvements; however, validity was in question

The use of frequency modulation (FM) listening devices can enhance speech perception in noise, aid social interaction, and improve educational outcomes in children with ASD(61) –Based on a study conducted in Sweden that involved 20 children with ASD –Hearing difficulties are common. Twelve of the 20 children in the study met the clinical definition for central auditory processing disorder –The provision of FM listening devices ameliorated auditory processing problems and resulted in improved listening, attention, and social interaction

The Robota project –Small, child-like  robots are being created and studied in Switzerland for their potential capacity to facilitate growth in various domains in children with ASD. Through interaction with these robots, the hope is that the child’s communication with other persons will improve(43)

Music therapy –Music therapy for children with an ASD might improve communication abilities(44) -Systematic review of 3 randomized controlled trials; 24 children with ASD in total -Brief music therapy interventions (daily sessions over 1 week) associated with significantly improved verbal communicative skills and significantly improved nonverbal/gestural communicative skills

Virtual reality –Literature has suggested the use of virtual reality (i.e., computer-simulated  environments with which an individual can interact) as a treatment intervention for individuals with ASD, but more extensive randomized trials are needed(45) -Might allow for concept acquisition -Concept of size -Concept of position -Concept of time -Concept of quantity -Might allow for social growth -Repeated exposure to facial expressions and words to reinforce emotional understanding -Exposure to nonliteral/figurative language -Symbolic play  ›For detailed information on AAC for children with ASD, see Clinical Review…Augmentative and Alternative Communication: Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709149 .
